metadata.template_skill: Student views two bars with the same number of pieces shaded (numerator > 1, different denominators) and selects the correct comparison symbol

telemetry_data.mastery_skill: Student can select the correct comparison symbol for same-numerator non-unit fractions by comparing piece sizes in bars

steps.dialogue: Look at these two bars. They both have three pieces shaded. Which fraction is greater?

step.dialogue: Not quite. Look at the size of the shaded pieces in each bar.
Let's think about this together. Both bars have 3 pieces shaded, but notice how the pieces are different sizes. When the same number of pieces are shaded, the fraction with bigger pieces is greater.

Let me walk you through comparing these fractions. Both bars have exactly 3 pieces shaded. But look at the size of those pieces. The first bar is divided into fourths - each piece is pretty big. The second bar is divided into eighths - each piece is much smaller. When we have the same count of pieces shaded, we compare the size of the pieces. Fourths are bigger than eighths, so 3 fourths covers more space than 3 eighths. That means 3/4 is greater than 3/8. That's how we compare fractions with the same numerator - the one with bigger pieces is greater.

on_correct.dialogue: Right. Same count, but bigger pieces win.
